title: Not A Casual Read
content: This is great book in so many ways. It is beautifully written - I did not find a single word or phrase that wasn't needed. Rosen tells a compelling story that makes the book hard to put down.  In addition to the drama of the story, it deals with an important issue for our time: How should we treat those with severe mental illness?  Rosen doesn't so much answer that question as intelligently and sensitively place the tragic story of his friend in the context of that issue.  Clearly, our mental health system did not work in this case as in so many others.  Finally, Rosen's voice in this book is a comfort.  He is a very wise and compassionate writer.  I am old and an avid reader, and this is one of the best books I have ever read.

title: Verified Purchase
content: The subtitle is what interested me. I have a “brilliant” brother, diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia, who murdered a family friend, was sentenced to life, and was paroled after serving 9 years and walked out with the loving support of family (including me) and friends, with a condition of his parole being that he must stay on his meds, only to quit taking his meds and then repeating the psychotic behavior that he exhibited before his crime. My father was required to file  charges against my brother to have him re-incarcerated after he began threatening family members because the parole officer said he couldn’t make my brother take his meds. I agree with the conclusions in this book of Owen Fiss that all of Michael’s supporters should have inquired into the possibility of violence.  The signs were there. My family didn’t make that inquiry and didn’t see the signs before the murder that my brother committed but did when my brother was out on parole. By that time, we knew what he was capable of.  It is the institution which provides the structure necessary for my brother to stay medicated and he has even refused to take his meds in prison in the years after his parole was revoked. This book will stay with me for a long time. The author has captured the very essence of this illness.

title: The Best Minds? Is Rosen included?
content: I just started reading Rosen’s book, The Best Minds about his long childhood friendship with Michael Laudon (who was ostensibly brilliant, schizophrenic, and who - during a psychotic episode - became a murderer). I was hoping that Laudon would be described by someone who genuinely liked & cared about him. But, within a few chapters, it feels like Laudon’s “friend” didn’t like him much at all - in fact, he appears to resent him and subsequently underscores Laudon’s negative attitudes, behaviors, etc. (rather than his positive qualities). With Rosen’s own emotions affecting how this story is reported, I’m finding it no longer an objective account of Laudor and his life’s journey, but rather a validation of why Rosen resented him. I’m hoping this changes in the upcoming chapters.

title: Verified Purchase
content: This is a good book, though not a great one.  On the positive side, the story is compelling and parts of it are marvelous.  Especially strong are the parts of the book that detail the dynamics of young friendship, and which document the peculiar cultural moment that was a 1970s childhood. title: Verified Purchase
content: Presumably, potential buyers of the book know that it's about a highly-educated man suffering from schizophrenia, who gruesomely murdered his pregnant girlfriend, so I'm not giving away any spoilers here.  That core story can't help but be riveting. But the book is way too long and meandering: the author attempts to explain how things went awry by dissecting every idiotic fad that became fashionable among academics and interest groups in the 1970s and 1980s.  These things richly deserve the damning scrutiny that the author applies to them, but it didn't need to be nearly so detailed.  We really don't require page after page detailing theories of literary criticism such as structuralism, or the inner workings of the cadre of activists dedicating themselves to pursuing deinstitutionalization of the mentally ill.  Yes, these warrant being covered, but the sheer depth and breadth of these diversions into half-baked academic philosophies detracts from the forward momentum of the story.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on May 30, 2023

title: Pardon the pun, but it's maddening
content: I couldn't help but come away from the book shaking my head at the foolishness of so many supposedly intelligent people, and thinking that the author's description of "best intentions" gone awry was far too generous.  Rather, it's a story about how academia and special-interest advocacy become incubation chambers for the most blame-fool concepts one can come up with, the sort of blather that is so ridiculous that only an intellectual can believe it.  Apparently, it makes people feel smart to theorize that there is no objective reality, that language exists only to support oppressive power structures, and that mental illness is actually a glimpse of higher truths to which the rest of us neurotypical people simply aren't privy.  But that feeling is unwarranted.

title: Over-hyped
content: It made countless privileged people feel good about themselves to argue that we should protect the mentally ill from discrimination in exactly the same way that we protect people from racial discrimination.  But it's patent nonsense, as anyone will realize if they spend even a moment thinking about it.  You don't give a toddler the keys to the family car, you don't allow a blind person to fly a plane or perform surgery, and you don't allow the paranoid delusional near weaponry.  And it doesn't matter how many times the person says, "But I really, really want to do this and you're mean if you don't let me," it's still fantastically negligent to do any of these things.
